STRATEGY.objection_type: INTERNAL - Her self-doubt about whether it'll work for HER body/style
STRATEGY.contrast: Micro Features handle this LOGISTICALLY in the Grid (cut/structure)

the_secret.type: INTERNAL (The Fit / Body Shape / Personal Style)
the_secret.meaning: Why she thinks 'it won't work on ME' - and why she's wrong
the_secret.philosophical_angle: She's been told her body is the problem. It's not. The DESIGN was the problem.

internal_doubts_to_address: It looks great on HER but I'm not that type
My body is different - this probably won't work for me
I could never pull that off
I don't have the style/personality for this
I'm not tall/thin/young enough for this

E_cognitive_disruption.what: Challenge her belief that SHE is the problem
E_cognitive_disruption.example: You've probably tried on a hundred things that didn't work. And every time, you blamed your body. Stop.

N_unfinished_story.what: Tell a story of someone who thought the same thing
N_unfinished_story.example: She was 5'2", size 14, and hadn't bought anything new in 3 years. 'Nothing ever looks right on me,' she said. Then she tried this on...

G_controversial_truth.what: Reveal why 'flattering' is a lie the industry tells
G_controversial_truth.example: Here's the truth no brand will tell you: 90% of clothes are designed for ONE body type. If you don't match it, you think YOU'RE wrong. You're not.

A_personal_stakes.what: Make it deeply emotional - the cost of believing she's the problem
A_personal_stakes.example: I know what it's like to stand in a fitting room, trying not to cry, wondering why nothing ever fits. That's not a you problem. That's a design problem.

G_unconventional_payoff.what: Promise how THIS design works for HER specifically
G_unconventional_payoff.example: This piece was designed for real bodies. Every curve, every cut, every seam was tested on women sizes 0-18. Not mannequins. Women.

E_time_locked_curiosity.what: Create urgency around finally finding something that works
E_time_locked_curiosity.example: The women who've found us? They're not going back. Because once you know what 'actually fits' feels like, you can't unsee it.

images.source: images/product/ OR lifestyle shots showing diverse body types
images.NOT: testimonial images (those are for Micro Features)

variables_output.SECRET_HEADLINE_2: [Disruptive headline about the Internal belief shift]

internal_angles_for_fashion: Body Type - Why clothes fail different shapes (and how this doesn't)
Age - Why she's not 'too old' for style (the youthfulness myth)
Personality - Why she CAN 'pull it off' (confidence follows fit)
Style Identity - Why she doesn't need to be 'fashion-forward' (timeless works)

tone_guidance.write_like: A supportive friend who finally helps her see it was never her fault
tone_guidance.voice: Warm, validating, gently indignant on her behalf
tone_guidance.MUST_USE: Exact language patterns from research-summary.md Voice & Tone

anti_laziness_check: Does this PHILOSOPHICALLY address her self-doubt?
Did I shift blame FROM her body TO the design?
Did I use all 6 ENGAGE elements?
Am I using PRODUCT/LIFESTYLE images (not testimonials)?
Would she feel PERMISSION to believe this is for her?
Did I avoid generic body positivity platitudes?
Did I use language from the research Voice & Tone section?
